{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3374425,"name":"John Fogarty","username":"JohnFogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T14:14:30.042Z","cooked":"

What we’ve learned this year is that instituting standard driven practices into our design process and team could make it easier to have multiple students work together on our parts and assemblies. I’m not the design and CAD mentor, but I think about these things from a software perspective and it’s not quite the same can of worms…

Problems I have seen include issues like…

Scenario A
One person creates a part that mounts a component at a specific angle and 3D prints it to test. The next meeting that student is not there and testing reveals that the part mounting angle needs to be changed. A second design student opens the part and discovers the modeling flow of sketches/3D edits is different from what they do and so they have a hard time figuring out how to edit the first student’s part. If we can’t get ahold of the original designer of said part we have to spend sometimes a lot of extra time either figuring out some way to edit the part to meet the changes needed or in the worst case remaking the same part again from the start.

Other problems I’ve seen…
Plate parts that are distinct left and right side in some specific features but share some common dimensions/holes/features. One person will change one side dimension, but forget to change the other side dimension.

A part design is done from a sketch by a person early in the season before strict requirements are known with rough geometry. Better requirements and dimensions are understood and another student comes behind them and wants to modify the original part. Attempts to change the part explodes the sketch or causes multiple under-defined parts to warp/shift.

I’m sure there are many other gotchas we’ve experienced this year…the point being. 1102 is new to having larger design teams… for better or worse since I became coach in 2018 our team has only had 1-2 students that are interested in touching CAD. That was something I wanted to see improved and this year we had 7 or more students that did some design for different aspects of the robot.

What are the standard processes your team uses to avoid common mistakes in CAD and help facilitate multiple team members working together on design?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T14:14:30.042Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":44,"reads":542,"readers_count":541,"score":543.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464615,"topic_slug":"cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":14}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes/464615/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":14}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":14,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3374454,"name":"Brandon","username":"bdon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bdon/{size}/176951_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T14:52:35.217Z","cooked":"

A second design student opens the part and discovers the modeling flow of sketches/3D edits is different from what they do and so they have a hard time figuring out how to edit the first student’s part.

This is a problem we’ve run into a few times this season as well, as we’re trying out new processes and some students are doing things intuitive to them but aren’t immediately obvious to everyone else. To fix this, we’re going to be doing a lot of offseason training and practice with a huge focus on good practices and modular CAD. It’s super important to have the important driving dimensions defined first (eg. wheel sizes, wheel compression, C-C distances), then supporting dimensions (eg. fastener locations, plate geometry). Pocketing should be the last feature of a part, as it’s the most prone to breaking and least crucial element that determines the function of the part.

Plate parts that are distinct left and right side in some specific features but share some common dimensions/holes/features. One person will change one side dimension, but forget to change the other side dimension.

One method of designing big assemblies is to use a top-down design workflow, where the overall system is planned out first as a sketch or as a part, then parts are derived from that. As a SolidWorks user I’m not sure what this process looks like in OnShape, but generally the process involves creating a layout sketch with all the important dimensions, then parts are defined according to that sketch. This way, when you need to change a crucial dimension, it only needs to be changed in one sketch and everything that depends on that sketch will update automatically.

Attempts to change the part explodes the sketch or causes multiple under-defined parts to warp/shift.

This sounds like the initial sketch was not super well defined. I don’t have a quick and easy answer for this, but I find that it’s often in the details of how some sketch relations are fighting some dimensions. I’ve also gotten much better at dealing with overdefined sketches in terms of knowing what dimensions/relations are fighting, which really helps that sketch-fixing process.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T14:52:35.217Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":455,"readers_count":454,"score":146.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464615,"topic_slug":"cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes","display_username":"Brandon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53655,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4476 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes/464615/2","custom_user_title":"4476 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3374474,"name":"Camren","username":"Camren","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/camren/{size}/226239_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T15:12:05.517Z","cooked":"

I would ensure students always fully define their sketches/assemblies even if the geometry is rough. It is easier to handle the broken reference errors than exploded sketches/assemblies. Also, a little documentation goes a long way. After a design session we publish notes into our discord that include screenshots and some context of design intent.

JohnFogarty:

Plate parts that are distinct left and right side

I train my students to avoid this at all costs. Design for Manufacturing/Assembly/Serviceability is at the fore front of my training sessions.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T15:12:05.517Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":359,"readers_count":358,"score":116.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464615,"topic_slug":"cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes","display_username":"Camren","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16209,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes/464615/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3374531,"name":"Ardiano Works","username":"MSU2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msu2000/{size}/190139_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T16:28:05.168Z","cooked":"

We’ve used Fusion360, no model Tree, no constraints. Student can change it however they want to change it, you don’t need to understand how someone created the model, what you see is what you get. Direct modeling is also quicker to get your idea to completion. Cleaner package too. I’ve used SW for decades for big and small assy, and currently training my kids with Fusion 360. Their CAM package is awesome too. SW Cam is pain in the butt, MAsterCAM is expensive.

As far as CAD assy process. Break it up into subsystems and have a lead designer owns the entire system, while others developing it.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T17:22:47.081Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":329,"readers_count":328,"score":75.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464615,"topic_slug":"cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes","display_username":"Ardiano Works","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57747,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes/464615/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3374561,"name":"Phil Szymanowski","username":"Cyberphil","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T16:44:11.859Z","cooked":"

This is a pretty hot take… I don’t think it’s a good one either, but if it works for you and your team, by all means. I promise you that direct modeling will not help your students be prepared for designing anything more than animation scenes though.

I guarantee most teams do not use direct modeling for good reason. It’s a nightmare to refine ideas without messing something up you previously did. With simple designs and some experience it can be handy, but as your system gets more complex, which is almost always the tendency, you will quickly grow frustrated.

I’d be curious to see your model. Is that something you can share, or even a few screenshots?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T16:44:11.859Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":302,"readers_count":301,"score":120.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464615,"topic_slug":"cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes","display_username":"Phil Szymanowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57747,"username":"MSU2000","name":"Ardiano Works","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msu2000/{size}/190139_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10874,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)"},"post_url":"/t/cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes/464615/5","custom_user_title":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3374573,"name":"Phil Szymanowski","username":"Cyberphil","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T16:59:00.172Z","cooked":"

One thing that is really difficult to pickup on with CAD is designing to show your design intent. It’s a difficult thing in all honesty, and it comes eventually with enough experience.

A quick example of what I mean by design intent:
You are designing a car and are sizing the wheels. You know that if you use 20" wheels the center of the tire will be 10" off the ground. You draw a 20" wheel and dimension the center 10" off the ground, so the wheel is tangent to the ground.

But let’s say you decide later you want 22" wheels, or you just want to see what 24" wheels would look like. You change the wheel diameter dimension and now your wheel is sticking through the ground, something wheels can’t physically do, so then you also have to change the wheel center dimension to account for this. This is CADing without showing the design intent,

CADing while showing design intent would instead constrain the wheel tangentially to the ground so that no matter what the diameter is the wheel will always be on the ground.

This is a simplistic example, but attempt to implement this in every single sketch and feature you make. Constrain and dimension sketches, putting as much effort and thought possible to the design intent of those constraints. This makes making changes to the design later on significantly easier.

This gets significantly more complex with more parts and major changes to robot design or architecture. Your model may explode, it happens to everyone. A better skill is learning to un-explode it, which helps to understand how prevent that from happening in the future.

Regarding LH and RH version of parts, create as many features of the part first and then Mirror it while keeping the reference to the original part. Then you only need to change the features on one part and those changes will reflect to the mirrored part automatically. If you need to make the LH and RH versions different later, you can always split them apart, but do this as late in the design as possible.

Echoing others here, ALWAYS fully define your sketches. The only sketches that should be left undefined are ones you are using for the explicit purpose of seeing the motion of some component. Do not use that sketch to make the part either, use a fully-defined sketch.

Just curious, what software does 1102 use?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T16:59:00.172Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":269,"readers_count":268,"score":133.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464615,"topic_slug":"cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes","display_username":"Phil Szymanowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10874,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)"},"post_url":"/t/cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes/464615/6","custom_user_title":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3374585,"name":"John Fogarty","username":"JohnFogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T17:12:00.163Z","cooked":"

We are using OnShape.

I’m not absolutely certain we will stick with it, but it seems likely due to ease of access for the students.
There has been some discussions about the fact none of our local employers use OnShape. EG…the savannah river national lab employees use PTC CREO and most other mentors use Solidworks at work. I think this has lead to some gaps in our ability at times to be able to quickly help the kids with some of the more nuanced aspects of OnShape at times.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T17:12:00.163Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":231,"readers_count":230,"score":61.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464615,"topic_slug":"cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes/464615/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3374603,"name":"Sanjeev","username":"jeevsan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jeevsan/{size}/218660_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T17:25:29.401Z","cooked":"
Brandon:

I’m not sure what this process looks like in OnShape

At least on our team, we use a “master sketch” in one of the part studios, import it into an assembly and overlay it on top of the drivetrain. A really good way that helped us as a team get started was the Onshape top-down design course that is free and set up some good fundamentals.

To add on, group off-season projects help, where the CAD team sits down and makes a component (254’s end-effector in 2019 for example). It helps setup good fundementals. I think, especially with a bigger team with a wide range of computer capabilities, Onshape is a really good platform to use. Another resource is the 3005 Onshape Course. A general training sets the general design philosophy for a team and helps avoid such issues.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T17:25:29.401Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":234,"readers_count":233,"score":91.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464615,"topic_slug":"cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes","display_username":"Sanjeev","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://learn.onshape.com/learning-paths/top-down-design","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Onshape Learning Center","clicks":17},{"url":"https://onshape4frc.com/robochargers-curriculum#week1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 3005 RoboChargers Onshape CAD Class | Onshape4FRC","clicks":10}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59559,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Benzene Bots | Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes/464615/8","custom_user_title":"Benzene Bots | Electrical Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3374663,"name":"Phil Szymanowski","username":"Cyberphil","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T18:34:08.217Z","cooked":"

I highly suggest you stick with Onshape. These problems will only get worse if you use another software. Part-studio modeling, where you make all of your parts in-context to each other, make designing individual much more intuitive, especially so to new users in my experience.

Would you consider sharing your document here? I might be able to give some pointers on how things were built from the beginning.

Creo and SolidWorks do have some differences from Onshape (Creo much more so), but they have more in common than not. It’s possible the mentors are unfamiliar with some of the techniques we’re talking about here as well. If they are up for it, I highly suggest some mentors take some time to model a few things up to get more familiar with the software. I found the biggest major difference was the mating/assemblies. The solid modeling is nearly identical to Solidworks with a few small nuances though.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T18:34:08.217Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":224,"readers_count":223,"score":59.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464615,"topic_slug":"cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes","display_username":"Phil Szymanowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12688,"username":"JohnFogarty","name":"John Fogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10874,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)"},"post_url":"/t/cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes/464615/9","custom_user_title":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3374825,"name":"John Fogarty","username":"JohnFogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T21:48:11.510Z","cooked":"

I’m going to ask some of the students on the design team to contribute to this discussion and post some files here. I think they could also highlight more pain points of the season than I can. The master assembly that I see has copies of parts that don’t link back to the editable ones… and I don’t know why.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T21:48:11.510Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":196,"readers_count":195,"score":44.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464615,"topic_slug":"cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":10874,"username":"Cyberphil","name":"Phil Szymanowski","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-design-team-standard-driven-processes/464615/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3374834,"name":"Chun-che Lo","username":"Attention","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/attention/{size}/65287_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T22:04:01.841Z","cooked":"

When you right click and select “go to …”, it opens a versioned studio of the part or assembly. You need to then get back in the main branch of the part or assembly studio to edit the part.

There should be a button that says return to main in the top leftish.

I think that’s what’s happening. I could be wrong.

We are on Fusion 360. I’ve been trying to find videos/classes/anything that would help our students understands more about Design Intent from the top down as you have described. Do you have any pointers/resources that you don’t mind sharing?

Thanks.

Our mechanical mentor who has gotten us onto Fusion 360 has to take leave since he now has couple young children and can’t commit the kind of time that the team need. I’m a EE with System/Programming/IT background and I can do enough of CAD to get by and do up the simple subcomponents and help students understands stuff but really not the right person to really teach them CAD. We have setup Fusion CAM to split out gcode for our Xcarve where I can cut wood/lexan/alumnium for our robot so really not looking to do a full on switch to another platform unless their CAM will get us similar thing without hugh cost or learning curve.

Unfortunately there aren’t a lot of resources focused on this relatively high-level CAD technique. Most resources are focused on getting people familiar with basic functionality. Honestly, I learned this methodology almost completely on my own. I’ve considered doing a training on it, but it’s so design-specific I feel it would be hard to translate the ideas to other designs.

Do people think that would be helpful?

I have coworkers who have been modeling for 15+ years who still don’t model this way and are completely successful. It’s certainly not necessary to use this, but it is incredibly helpful in places like robotics where the design is changing continuously early in the process.

To illustrate the points being made in Onshape. This is how we did our “indexer” and shooter.

Isometric view of the parts:

Iso view677×836 199 KB

Side View:

Side View980×680 210 KB

All the parts are:

  • In the same part studio
  • Referenced off a “Master” part via constraints.
  • So if we want to do something like change the belt spacing, all we need to do is change 1 sketch then all the other parts follow.

Working assumptions / Notes:

  • Use Hole Tool as a feature referenced to a dimensioned vertex (i.e., don’t draw a hole in the ketch, draw a vertex. If you need a reference, then use Construction lines).
  • Don’t do things like putting radii in the sketch, use the radius tool for that.
  • Feature scripts are your friend - part lightening is a couple of clicks with the correct feature script.

Finished for reference:

shooter indexer1122×887 103 KB
